LSUs Student Health Center has confirmed several student cases of mumps which was communicated to students and faculty in a Division of Strategic Communications email on Tuesday PERIOD

Mumps is a contagious disease spread by contactwith infectious respiratory tract secretions and saliva PERIOD

Students with swollen and tender salivary glands under the ears or jaw on one or both sides of the face should seek care at the Student Health Center or with their primary care provider PERIOD Students with signs of mumps must be kept in isolation for at least five days from the onset of salivary gland swelling PERIOD

While there is no specific treatment for mumps most people recover fully PERIOD However mumps can occasionallycause serious complications according to the Student Health Center PERIOD

The Student Health Center recommends good hand washing not eating or drinking after others and covering ones nose and mouth with a tissue when coughing or sneezing to help prevent transmission of the disease PERIOD

Receiving two doses of the measles mumps and rubella MMR vaccine is the best way to prevent pumps PERIOD This vaccine is currently required for all students at the University PERIOD Most students on campus should be protected due to the vaccine according to the Student Health Center but the vaccine is not  effective PERIOD

Anyone who has not received two doses of the MMR vaccine is recommended to get the vaccine as soon as possible PERIOD A third MMR vaccine is recommended for anyone who has come into contact with someone currently diagnosed with mumps PERIOD
